title: What Is a Linux Distribution? What Is Ubuntu?
note: This section explains that a 'Linux Distribution' (or distro) is a complete operating system made from the Linux kernel and a collection of software. It then introduces Ubuntu as a popular, user-friendly, and free distro based on Debian, known for its ease of use and strong community.

title: Ubuntu Releases: LTS vs. Regular
note: This lesson explains Ubuntu's release schedule. It covers the difference between Long-Term Support (LTS) releases, which are published every two years and supported for five years (making them stable and reliable for production), and the regular releases that come out every six months with newer features.

title: Installing Ubuntu Desktop
note: This section provides a practical guide to installing Ubuntu Desktop. It covers the steps of downloading the ISO image, creating a bootable USB drive, booting from the USB, and walking through the graphical installation wizard.

title: Navigating the Ubuntu Desktop (GNOME)
note: This lesson provides a guided tour of the default Ubuntu desktop environment, GNOME. It explains the main components: the Activities overview for launching apps and managing workspaces, the top bar, and the Ubuntu Dock for quick access to favorite and running applications.

title: Installing Software with the Ubuntu Software Center
note: This section demonstrates the easiest way to install applications on Ubuntu Desktop. It introduces the Ubuntu Software center, a graphical 'app store' that allows you to browse, search for, and install thousands of applications with a single click.

title: Introduction to the Command Line (Terminal)
note: This lesson explains how to open the Terminal and introduces the command line as the most powerful way to interact with a Linux system. The concept of a shell (like Bash) that interprets your commands is explained.

title: Essential Navigation Commands
note: This section covers the most fundamental commands for moving around the file system. It demonstrates `pwd` (print working directory), `ls` (list files and directories), and `cd` (change directory).

title: Managing Files and Directories
note: This lesson introduces the commands for creating and deleting files and directories. It covers `mkdir` (make directory), `touch` (create an empty file), `cp` (copy), `mv` (move or rename), and `rm` (remove).

title: Getting Help with `man` and `--help`
note: This crucial lesson explains how to get help directly from the command line. It introduces the `man` command (for viewing the 'manual' page of another command) and the common `--help` flag, which most commands support to show a brief summary of their usage.

title: Software Management with `apt`
note: This section introduces `apt` (Advanced Package Tool) as the command-line tool for managing software on Ubuntu. It explains that `apt` works with 'packages' and handles dependencies automatically.

title: Using `apt`: `update`, `upgrade`, `install`, `remove`
note: This lesson demonstrates the most common `apt` commands. It covers `sudo apt update` (to refresh the list of available packages), `sudo apt upgrade` (to install updates), `sudo apt install <package>` (to install a new package), and `sudo apt remove <package>` (to uninstall a package).

title: Managing Users with `sudo`
note: This section explains that administrative tasks require elevated privileges, which are gained by prepending a command with `sudo`. It then demonstrates how to add a new user with `sudo adduser <username>`.

title: Understanding File Permissions
note: This lesson provides an overview of the Linux file permission system. It explains the read (r), write (w), and execute (x) permissions for the three types of owners: the user, the group, and others. The `chmod` command is introduced for changing permissions.

title: Installing Ubuntu Server
note: This section provides an overview of the Ubuntu Server installation process. It highlights the differences from the Desktop installation, such as the text-based installer and the options to install common server software (like an SSH server) during setup.

title: Connecting to a Server with SSH
note: This lesson explains that servers are typically managed remotely. It introduces Secure Shell (SSH) as the standard protocol for securely connecting to the command line of a remote Linux server. The basic `ssh user@hostname` command is demonstrated.

title: Managing Services with `systemd`
note: This section covers how to manage background services (daemons) on an Ubuntu server using `systemd`. It introduces the `systemctl` command for starting, stopping, and checking the status of services, such as the `apache2` web server.

title: Configuring the Firewall with UFW
note: This lesson introduces `ufw` (Uncomplicated Firewall) as a user-friendly frontend for managing firewall rules on Ubuntu. It demonstrates how to enable the firewall and allow traffic for specific services, like SSH and HTTP.

title: Server Networking with Netplan
note: This section explains that modern Ubuntu servers use Netplan for network configuration. It provides an overview of the YAML-based configuration files located in `/etc/netplan` and how to apply changes.

title: Introduction to Snap Packages
note: This lesson introduces Snaps as a newer, containerized software package format developed by Canonical (the company behind Ubuntu). It explains that Snaps bundle their dependencies and can run on any Linux distribution, and demonstrates the `snap install` command.

title: Project: Setting Up a LAMP Stack
note: This final lesson provides a practical project. It walks through the steps of installing a LAMP stack (Linux, Apache, MySQL/MariaDB, PHP) on an Ubuntu server, which is a common software bundle for hosting dynamic websites.
